content.text: This is a HE WSI of a CRC case, consisting of lymph nodes or primary tumor section. What is your initial impression of this image?

I see approximately seven separate pieces of tissue on this slide. Most appear to be lymph nodes, characterized by their ovoid shape and dense, basophilic (purple) cellularity, embedded in pale adipose tissue. Some nodes appear completely effaced by the dense cellular infiltrate, while others retain a more typical architecture with a visible hilum or capsule. The task is to identify any positive (metastatic) nodes.
Are there any places you want to look into further? Give me reasons why you want to look into each region.

I am systematically examining each potential lymph node. This is the first node located in the top-left corner. I have zoomed into the lower portion of this node, near the hilum/subcapsular area, because it appears slightly paler and more disrupted on the low-power view compared to the more uniform dark purple of the rest of the node. Such architectural alterations are suspicious for metastatic deposits, which often first appear in the subcapsular or medullary sinuses. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I am starting my systematic review of the lymph nodes, beginning with the one in the top-left corner. The zoomed-in area is at the periphery of the lymph node, right under the capsule and adjacent to the surrounding fat. This is a critical area to inspect because metastatic tumor cells typically first arrive and implant in the subcapsular sinus, which is located just beneath the capsule. I am examining this region at high power to look for any atypical cells or glandular structures that would indicate metastasis. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, my goal is to systematically examine every lymph node to definitively rule in or rule out the presence of metastatic tumor cells. This particular node, the fifth one I would examine in a systematic top-to-bottom, left-to-right review, is being evaluated as part of this routine screening. At low power, it appears to be a lymph node, but high-power examination is essential to identify any subtle tumor deposits (micrometastases) that would otherwise be missed. I am looking for any non-lymphoid cell clusters, abnormal glandular structures, or cells with atypical features. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I am zooming into this area as part of a systematic screening of all the lymph nodes provided. This particular node, located in the bottom right, is one of the larger ones. I am examining its internal structure to identify any potential metastatic tumor deposits, which would appear as clusters of atypical, non-lymphoid cells, often forming glands, contrasting with the normal lymphoid tissue. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I am zooming into this specific area on the largest lymph node in the bottom row (second from right) because it appears to be almost entirely replaced by tumor. The purpose of this zoom is twofold: firstly, to confirm at high power that the dense cellular infiltrate is indeed metastatic adenocarcinoma, and secondly, and more importantly, to carefully examine the border between the tumor-infiltrated node and the surrounding adipose tissue to assess for extranodal extension (ENE). ENE is a critical prognostic factor and must be reported. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, the task is to examine every lymph node on the slide for evidence of cancer metastasis. The zoom is directed at the first lymph node from the top right. I would systematically examine each tissue fragment at higher magnification. This particular node has a somewhat irregular, lobulated contour, which warrants a closer look to determine if the irregularity is due to tumor infiltration or a benign reactive process. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, my standard procedure is to systematically examine every piece of tissue that could be a lymph node to check for the presence of metastatic cancer. The area highlighted by the green box is one of these discrete tissue fragments, specifically the second one from the top in the middle. I am zooming in to assess its architecture and cellular composition at high magnification to determine if it is indeed a lymph node and if it contains any tumor cells. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, my protocol for staging colorectal cancer requires the meticulous examination of every single lymph node submitted, regardless of its size. The green box is over the fourth lymph node from the top (starting from the top left and moving across). Even small nodes like this one can contain micrometastases, which are crucial for accurate staging. Therefore, I am zooming into this area as part of a systematic review of all the lymph nodes on the slide to search for any evidence of tumor cells. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found].
This is ROI 1 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this high-power view, I see the parenchyma of a lymph node, which is composed of a dense population of small, dark lymphocytes. However, infiltrating the sinuses and disrupting the normal lymphoid architecture are several nests and small, poorly-formed glands of atypical cells. These cells are larger than the surrounding lymphocytes, have more abundant eosinophilic (pink) cytoplasm, and large, pleomorphic, hyperchromatic nuclei. This morphology is characteristic of metastatic adenocarcinoma. My impression is that this is a positive lymph node containing metastatic colorectal adenocarcinoma.
This is ROI 2 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

This high-power view shows the interface between the lymph node and the surrounding perinodal adipose tissue (fat). The bulk of the image consists of a dense population of small, dark-staining lymphocytes, which is characteristic of lymph node parenchyma. The lymph node capsule is visible at the junction with the fat. I do not see any atypical epithelial cells, nests of tumor cells, or abnormal glandular formations within the subcapsular sinus or infiltrating the capsule. My impression of this specific area is that it is a benign/reactive lymph node, and there is no evidence of metastasis in this field of view.
This is ROI 3 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this high-magnification view, I see the typical architecture of a lymph node. There are prominent, well-circumscribed lymphoid follicles, one of which is centrally located in the field of view. This follicle has a germinal center (the paler central area) and a surrounding mantle zone (the darker rim of small lymphocytes). The surrounding tissue consists of a dense population of various lymphocytes and some red blood cells (minor hemorrhage). Crucially, I do not see any atypical epithelial cells, abnormal glands, or cohesive nests of malignant cells. My impression is that this is a reactive lymph node, showing follicular hyperplasia, which is a benign finding. This area is negative for metastasis.
This is ROI 4 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this high-power view, I see a dense population of small, dark, round cells, which are characteristic of lymphocytes. The tissue architecture shows features of a reactive lymph node, with prominent lymphoid follicles and interfollicular areas. There are some areas with slight hemorrhage (red blood cells) within the sinuses. Importantly, I do not see any clusters of atypical epithelial cells, abnormal gland formation, or other features of metastatic carcinoma. My impression for this field is that of a benign, reactive lymph node, negative for metastasis.
This is ROI 5 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this high-magnification view, I see a large deposit of metastatic adenocarcinoma, characterized by densely packed nests of malignant cells with large, hyperchromatic, and pleomorphic nuclei. This confirms the node is positive. A small, residual lymphoid follicle is also visible, confirming the tissue of origin is a lymph node. The tumor mass is seen directly abutting the surrounding mature adipose tissue. The interface is irregular, and it appears the tumor has breached the lymph node capsule. My impression is a positive lymph node with extensive metastatic carcinoma and evidence highly suspicious for extranodal extension.
This is ROI 6 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

The zoomed-in view shows a cross-section of a lymph node. The normal architecture is partially effaced by numerous, back-to-back, and variably sized lymphoid follicles, which are the dense, dark purple nodules. This pattern is characteristic of marked follicular hyperplasia, a benign reactive change. I am looking for metastatic colorectal adenocarcinoma, which would typically appear as nests of atypical glandular structures or clusters of malignant epithelial cells with large, irregular nuclei and prominent nucleoli. In this specific high-power view, I do not see any definitive evidence of metastatic carcinoma. My impression is that this is a reactive lymph node, not a positive (metastatic) node.
This is ROI 7 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

The zoomed-in image reveals a lymph node surrounded by mature adipose (fat) tissue. The node is composed of a dense and diffuse population of small, dark lymphocytes. I do not see any definitive evidence of metastatic carcinoma; there are no atypical glandular structures, nests of large pleomorphic cells, or extracellular mucin pools that would be characteristic of colorectal adenocarcinoma metastasis. My impression of this specific field of view is a lymph node that is negative for malignancy.
This is ROI 8 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this zoomed-in view, I see a section of a lymph node adjacent to adipose tissue. The tissue is composed of a dense population of lymphocytes. There are some follicular structures, but they are not very distinct. I also observe some areas of hemorrhage (pink/red areas) and sinus histiocytosis, which are features of a reactive lymph node. I do not see definitive clusters of atypical glandular cells that would indicate metastatic adenocarcinoma. My initial impression is that this is a benign, reactive lymph node, but I would need to carefully examine the entire node, especially the subcapsular sinus, to confidently rule out a micrometastasis.
